1005.name: NOT_FOUND_ACCESS_POINT
1005.message:
Unable to find a Wi-Fi network.

Please confirm that your Wi-Fi
network is set up for use and that
the SSID has been set correctly.
You can check the Wii U SSID
settings under the Internet option
in System Settings.

If the Wi-Fi network is secured using
WEP, the security key you entered
may be incorrect.

Unplug your wireless router from the
power outlet. After a little while, plug
it back in and try again.

Make sure the Wii U console is within
range of your wireless router.

Move any electronics away from the
Wii U console and your wireless
router.

Try changing the wireless channel
within the settings of your wireless
router.

If you are unable to access or change
your wireless-router settings, please
contact the manufacturer for support.

If the problem persists, please visit
support.nintendo.com.
1005.short_description: The console was unable to find a Wi-FI network to connect to.
1005.long_description: (CONNECTION SLOT 5) The console was unable to find a Wi-Fi network to connect to, or ones were found but the SSID is invalid.
1005.short_solution: Make sure your console is in range of your Wi-Fi network. Power cycle the modem/router and ensure the router supports 2.4GHz connections.
1005.long_solution: Make sure your console is in range of your Wi-Fi network. Power cycle your modem/router. Check that the router supports 2.4GHz connections and also ensure that there aren't any large objects containing metals or other electronic devices between the console and the router that could interfere with connection. Most Wi-Fi routers will support both 2.4GHz and 5GHz and are able to transmit both simultaneously, but some may not.
